text:
The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise

Writing involves planning, translating ideas into text, and reviewing—often recursively. Expert writers set goals, draft toward them, and revise for meaning before surface edits.

metadata.title: The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise
metadata.retrieval_queries: Flower Hayes cognitive process writing | revision higher order concerns
metadata.citations: A Cognitive Process Theory of Writing - College Composition and Communication (Flower & Hayes, 1981)
metadata.text:
The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise

Writing involves planning, translating ideas into text, and reviewing—often recursively. Expert writers set goals, draft toward them, and revise for meaning before surface edits.

text:
Learning objectives for The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise:
Describe writing as iterative problem‑solving, not linear stages.
Plan and revise with explicit goals and criteria.

metadata.title: The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise
metadata.retrieval_queries: Flower Hayes cognitive process writing | revision higher order concerns
metadata.citations: A Cognitive Process Theory of Writing - College Composition and Communication (Flower & Hayes, 1981)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise:
Describe writing as iterative problem‑solving, not linear stages.
Plan and revise with explicit goals and criteria.

text:
Misconception 1: Good writers produce perfect first drafts.
Refutation: They revise extensively.
Explanation: Revision reshapes ideas, structure, and evidence.

Misconception 2: Revision equals proofreading.
Refutation: Higher‑order changes come first.
Explanation: Content and structure precede sentence‑level edits.

metadata.title: The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise
metadata.retrieval_queries: Flower Hayes cognitive process writing | revision higher order concerns
metadata.citations: A Cognitive Process Theory of Writing - College Composition and Communication (Flower & Hayes, 1981)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Good writers produce perfect first drafts.
Refutation: They revise extensively.
Explanation: Revision reshapes ideas, structure, and evidence.

Misconception 2: Revision equals proofreading.
Refutation: Higher‑order changes come first.
Explanation: Content and structure precede sentence‑level edits.

text:
Question 1: Which comes first in revision: thesis/structure or commas?
Answer: Thesis/structure
Rationale: Higher‑order concerns change what sentences should say.

Question 2: Is planning a separate step or interleaved with drafting?
Answer: Interleaved
Rationale: Writers cycle between planning and drafting.

metadata.title: The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise
metadata.retrieval_queries: Flower Hayes cognitive process writing | revision higher order concerns
metadata.citations: A Cognitive Process Theory of Writing - College Composition and Communication (Flower & Hayes, 1981)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which comes first in revision: thesis/structure or commas?
Answer: Thesis/structure
Rationale: Higher‑order concerns change what sentences should say.

Question 2: Is planning a separate step or interleaved with drafting?
Answer: Interleaved
Rationale: Writers cycle between planning and drafting.

text:
Worked Example for The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise:
Step: Write a thesis + 3 subgoals. - Why: Sets direction for drafting.
Step: Draft quickly toward the goals. - Why: Gets ideas down.
Step: Create a reverse outline (1 sentence per paragraph). - Why: Checks structure vs goals.
Step: Revise order and topic sentences; then edit sentences. - Why: HO → LO sequence.

metadata.title: The Writing Process: Plan → Draft → Revise
metadata.retrieval_queries: Flower Hayes cognitive process writing | revision higher order concerns

Step: Write a thesis + 3 subgoals. - Why: Sets direction for drafting.
Step: Draft quickly toward the goals. - Why: Gets ideas down.
Step: Create a reverse outline (1 sentence per paragraph). - Why: Checks structure vs goals.
Step: Revise order and topic sentences; then edit sentences. - Why: HO → LO sequence.

text:
Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)

Strong academic arguments articulate a claim and link reasons to evidence via warrants. Anticipating counterarguments strengthens credibility.

metadata.title: Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)
metadata.retrieval_queries: Toulmin model claim warrant backing rebuttal | thesis vs topic examples
metadata.citations: The Uses of Argument - Cambridge University Press (Toulmin, 1958/2003)
metadata.text:
Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)

Strong academic arguments articulate a claim and link reasons to evidence via warrants. Anticipating counterarguments strengthens credibility.

text:
Learning objectives for Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model):
Formulate a contestable thesis with clear reasons and evidence.
Use the Toulmin model (claim, reasons, evidence, warrant, backing, rebuttal).

metadata.title: Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)
metadata.retrieval_queries: Toulmin model claim warrant backing rebuttal | thesis vs topic examples
metadata.citations: The Uses of Argument - Cambridge University Press (Toulmin, 1958/2003)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model):
Formulate a contestable thesis with clear reasons and evidence.
Use the Toulmin model (claim, reasons, evidence, warrant, backing, rebuttal).

text:
Misconception 1: A topic equals a thesis.
Refutation: A thesis makes a claim that can be argued.
Explanation: It states a position with reasons.

Misconception 2: Evidence speaks for itself.
Refutation: Readers need warrants.
Explanation: Explain how evidence supports the claim.

metadata.title: Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)
metadata.retrieval_queries: Toulmin model claim warrant backing rebuttal | thesis vs topic examples
metadata.citations: The Uses of Argument - Cambridge University Press (Toulmin, 1958/2003)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: A topic equals a thesis.
Refutation: A thesis makes a claim that can be argued.
Explanation: It states a position with reasons.

Misconception 2: Evidence speaks for itself.
Refutation: Readers need warrants.
Explanation: Explain how evidence supports the claim.

text:
Question 1: Which element links evidence to claim?
Answer: Warrant
Rationale: It’s the reasoning bridge.

Question 2: Why include rebuttals?
Answer: To show awareness of limits and strengthen ethos
Rationale: Addressing counterpoints builds credibility.

metadata.title: Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)
metadata.retrieval_queries: Toulmin model claim warrant backing rebuttal | thesis vs topic examples
metadata.citations: The Uses of Argument - Cambridge University Press (Toulmin, 1958/2003)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which element links evidence to claim?
Answer: Warrant
Rationale: It’s the reasoning bridge.

Question 2: Why include rebuttals?
Answer: To show awareness of limits and strengthen ethos
Rationale: Addressing counterpoints builds credibility.

text:
Worked Example for Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model):
Step: Write claim + 2 reasons. - Why: Defines core argument.
Step: List evidence for each reason. - Why: Grounds the claim.
Step: State the warrant for a key piece of evidence. - Why: Shows logic.
Step: Add a counterclaim + rebuttal plan. - Why: Prepares balance.

metadata.title: Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model)
metadata.retrieval_queries: Toulmin model claim warrant backing rebuttal | thesis vs topic examples
metadata.citations: The Uses of Argument - Cambridge University Press (Toulmin, 1958/2003)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Thesis & Argument (Toulmin Model):
Step: Write claim + 2 reasons. - Why: Defines core argument.
Step: List evidence for each reason. - Why: Grounds the claim.
Step: State the warrant for a key piece of evidence. - Why: Shows logic.
Step: Add a counterclaim + rebuttal plan. - Why: Prepares balance.

text:
Structure of Academic Essays & Genres

Different fields favor different structures. Humanities essays argue a thesis; sciences often use IMRaD (Intro, Methods, Results, Discussion).

metadata.title: Structure of Academic Essays & Genres
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD structure example | essay structure thesis driven
metadata.citations: Writing Next (overview of effective practices) - Carnegie Corporation Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Structure of Academic Essays & Genres

Different fields favor different structures. Humanities essays argue a thesis; sciences often use IMRaD (Intro, Methods, Results, Discussion).

text:
Learning objectives for Structure of Academic Essays & Genres:
Differentiate common structures (IMRaD vs. thesis‑driven essay).
Outline an essay with logical flow and signposting.

metadata.title: Structure of Academic Essays & Genres
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD structure example | essay structure thesis driven
metadata.citations: Writing Next (overview of effective practices) - Carnegie Corporation Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Structure of Academic Essays & Genres:
Differentiate common structures (IMRaD vs. thesis‑driven essay).
Outline an essay with logical flow and signposting.

text:
Misconception 1: All essays follow the five‑paragraph formula.
Refutation: Structure should serve the argument and genre.
Explanation: Flexibility produces clarity and fit.

metadata.title: Structure of Academic Essays & Genres
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD structure example | essay structure thesis driven
metadata.citations: Writing Next (overview of effective practices) - Carnegie Corporation Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: All essays follow the five‑paragraph formula.
Refutation: Structure should serve the argument and genre.
Explanation: Flexibility produces clarity and fit.

text:
Question 1: Which genre typically uses IMRaD?
Answer: Scientific reports
Rationale: IMRaD is common in empirical research writing.

Question 2: What guides paragraph order?
Answer: Logic of the argument or story of the study
Rationale: Structure follows purpose.

metadata.title: Structure of Academic Essays & Genres
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD structure example | essay structure thesis driven
metadata.citations: Writing Next (overview of effective practices) - Carnegie Corporation Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which genre typically uses IMRaD?
Answer: Scientific reports
Rationale: IMRaD is common in empirical research writing.

Question 2: What guides paragraph order?
Answer: Logic of the argument or story of the study
Rationale: Structure follows purpose.

text:
Worked Example for Structure of Academic Essays & Genres:
Step: For the essay: intro → claims → evidence → counterargument → conclusion. - Why: Fits thesis‑driven argument.
Step: For the lab report: IMRaD headings with key questions per section. - Why: Fits empirical reporting.
Step: Add transitions and signposting. - Why: Improves reader navigation.
Step: Check alignment of structure with goals. - Why: Ensures fit.

metadata.title: Structure of Academic Essays & Genres
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD structure example | essay structure thesis driven
metadata.citations: Writing Next (overview of effective practices) - Carnegie Corporation Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Structure of Academic Essays & Genres:
Step: For the essay: intro → claims → evidence → counterargument → conclusion. - Why: Fits thesis‑driven argument.
Step: For the lab report: IMRaD headings with key questions per section. - Why: Fits empirical reporting.
Step: Add transitions and signposting. - Why: Improves reader navigation.
Step: Check alignment of structure with goals. - Why: Ensures fit.

text:
Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence

Effective paragraphs announce purpose, develop with evidence and reasoning, and maintain clear subject and verb focus. Cohesion comes from logical order and well‑placed transitions.

metadata.title: Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence
metadata.retrieval_queries: cohesion coherence paragraphs topic sentences | old new information flow writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback (for formative revision focus) - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence

Effective paragraphs announce purpose, develop with evidence and reasoning, and maintain clear subject and verb focus. Cohesion comes from logical order and well‑placed transitions.

text:
Learning objectives for Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence:
Write topic sentences that forecast purpose.
Use old→new information flow and transitions to build coherence.

metadata.title: Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence
metadata.retrieval_queries: cohesion coherence paragraphs topic sentences | old new information flow writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback (for formative revision focus) - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence:
Write topic sentences that forecast purpose.
Use old→new information flow and transitions to build coherence.

text:
Misconception 1: Transitions alone create coherence.
Refutation: Coherence requires clear topics and logic.
Explanation: Signposting supports but cannot replace structure.

metadata.title: Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence
metadata.retrieval_queries: cohesion coherence paragraphs topic sentences | old new information flow writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback (for formative revision focus) - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Transitions alone create coherence.
Refutation: Coherence requires clear topics and logic.
Explanation: Signposting supports but cannot replace structure.

text:
Question 1: Which improves coherence more: adding ‘however’ everywhere or revising topic sentences?
Answer: Revising topic sentences
Rationale: Topic sentences guide the whole paragraph.

Question 2: What is old→new flow?
Answer: Each sentence starts from known info and introduces new info
Rationale: It helps readers track ideas.

metadata.title: Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence
metadata.retrieval_queries: cohesion coherence paragraphs topic sentences | old new information flow writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback (for formative revision focus) - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which improves coherence more: adding ‘however’ everywhere or revising topic sentences?
Answer: Revising topic sentences
Rationale: Topic sentences guide the whole paragraph.

Question 2: What is old→new flow?
Answer: Each sentence starts from known info and introduces new info
Rationale: It helps readers track ideas.

text:
Worked Example for Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence:
Step: Write a precise topic sentence. - Why: Sets purpose.
Step: Order evidence to support the claim. - Why: Creates logical progression.
Step: Use transitions sparingly to mark shifts. - Why: Prevents clutter.
Step: Check subjects/verbs are concrete and active. - Why: Improves clarity.

metadata.title: Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence
metadata.retrieval_queries: cohesion coherence paragraphs topic sentences | old new information flow writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback (for formative revision focus) - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Paragraph Cohesion & Coherence:
Step: Write a precise topic sentence. - Why: Sets purpose.
Step: Order evidence to support the claim. - Why: Creates logical progression.
Step: Use transitions sparingly to mark shifts. - Why: Prevents clutter.
Step: Check subjects/verbs are concrete and active. - Why: Improves clarity.

text:
Using Evidence & Citation Ethically

Academic writing requires integrating sources with clear attribution and explanations of how evidence supports claims.

metadata.title: Using Evidence & Citation Ethically
metadata.retrieval_queries: paraphrase vs patchwriting academic integrity | explaining evidence with warrants
metadata.citations: Writing Next (evidence use and strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Using Evidence & Citation Ethically

Academic writing requires integrating sources with clear attribution and explanations of how evidence supports claims.

text:
Learning objectives for Using Evidence & Citation Ethically:
Integrate quotations, paraphrases, and summaries with attribution.
Explain evidence with warrants and avoid patchwriting.

metadata.title: Using Evidence & Citation Ethically
metadata.retrieval_queries: paraphrase vs patchwriting academic integrity | explaining evidence with warrants
metadata.citations: Writing Next (evidence use and strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Using Evidence & Citation Ethically:
Integrate quotations, paraphrases, and summaries with attribution.
Explain evidence with warrants and avoid patchwriting.

text:
Misconception 1: Citation alone proves a point.
Refutation: You must interpret evidence.
Explanation: Explain the link via warrants.

Misconception 2: Paraphrasing means word swapping.
Refutation: Paraphrase by re‑framing and condensing meaning.
Explanation: Patchwriting risks plagiarism and muddles logic.

metadata.title: Using Evidence & Citation Ethically
metadata.retrieval_queries: paraphrase vs patchwriting academic integrity | explaining evidence with warrants
metadata.citations: Writing Next (evidence use and strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Citation alone proves a point.
Refutation: You must interpret evidence.
Explanation: Explain the link via warrants.

Misconception 2: Paraphrasing means word swapping.
Refutation: Paraphrase by re‑framing and condensing meaning.
Explanation: Patchwriting risks plagiarism and muddles logic.

text:
Question 1: What must accompany a quote or paraphrase?
Answer: Explanation of its relevance
Rationale: Warrants connect evidence to claim.

Question 2: Is common knowledge cited?
Answer: No (with caution)
Rationale: When in doubt, cite.

metadata.title: Using Evidence & Citation Ethically
metadata.retrieval_queries: paraphrase vs patchwriting academic integrity | explaining evidence with warrants
metadata.citations: Writing Next (evidence use and strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: What must accompany a quote or paraphrase?
Answer: Explanation of its relevance
Rationale: Warrants connect evidence to claim.

Question 2: Is common knowledge cited?
Answer: No (with caution)
Rationale: When in doubt, cite.

text:
Worked Example for Using Evidence & Citation Ethically:
Step: Introduce source and context. - Why: Situates the reader.
Step: Present concise quote or paraphrase. - Why: Brings evidence.
Step: Explain how it supports your claim (warrant). - Why: Links evidence to thesis.
Step: Cite properly in the required style. - Why: Gives credit.

metadata.title: Using Evidence & Citation Ethically
metadata.retrieval_queries: paraphrase vs patchwriting academic integrity | explaining evidence with warrants
metadata.citations: Writing Next (evidence use and strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)

Worked Example for Using Evidence & Citation Ethically:
Step: Introduce source and context. - Why: Situates the reader.
Step: Present concise quote or paraphrase. - Why: Brings evidence.
Step: Explain how it supports your claim (warrant). - Why: Links evidence to thesis.
Step: Cite properly in the required style. - Why: Gives credit.

text:
Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)

A literature review summarizes and synthesizes, showing patterns, gaps, and debates—not just listing sources.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)
metadata.retrieval_queries: literature review synthesis vs summary | thematic clustering sources
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction, summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)

A literature review summarizes and synthesizes, showing patterns, gaps, and debates—not just listing sources.

text:
Learning objectives for Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves):
Group sources by themes, methods, or findings.
Write synthesis paragraphs that compare, contrast, and connect.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)
metadata.retrieval_queries: literature review synthesis vs summary | thematic clustering sources
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction, summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves):
Group sources by themes, methods, or findings.
Write synthesis paragraphs that compare, contrast, and connect.

text:
Misconception 1: A lit review is an annotated bibliography.
Refutation: It must connect sources.
Explanation: Synthesis reveals patterns and implications.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)
metadata.retrieval_queries: literature review synthesis vs summary | thematic clustering sources
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction, summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: A lit review is an annotated bibliography.
Refutation: It must connect sources.
Explanation: Synthesis reveals patterns and implications.

text:
Question 1: Which is stronger: source‑by‑source summary or thematic synthesis?
Answer: Thematic synthesis
Rationale: It builds a coherent story from sources.

Question 2: Should you include gaps or tensions?
Answer: Yes
Rationale: They motivate your project.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)
metadata.retrieval_queries: literature review synthesis vs summary | thematic clustering sources
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction, summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which is stronger: source‑by‑source summary or thematic synthesis?
Answer: Thematic synthesis
Rationale: It builds a coherent story from sources.

Question 2: Should you include gaps or tensions?
Answer: Yes
Rationale: They motivate your project.

text:
Worked Example for Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves):
Step: State the theme/question connecting them. - Why: Sets purpose.
Step: Compare methods/findings directly. - Why: Shows relationships.
Step: Explain agreement/disagreement implications. - Why: Adds interpretation.
Step: Conclude with what remains to be done. - Why: Points forward.

metadata.title: Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves)
metadata.retrieval_queries: literature review synthesis vs summary | thematic clustering sources
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction, summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Synthesizing Sources (Literature Review Moves):
Step: State the theme/question connecting them. - Why: Sets purpose.
Step: Compare methods/findings directly. - Why: Shows relationships.
Step: Explain agreement/disagreement implications. - Why: Adds interpretation.
Step: Conclude with what remains to be done. - Why: Points forward.

text:
Clarity & Style (Plain Language)

Clarity comes from concrete subjects, active verbs, and concise phrasing. Plain language improves comprehension for expert and novice readers alike.

metadata.title: Clarity & Style (Plain Language)
metadata.retrieval_queries: plain language academic writing evidence | revising for clarity active verbs
metadata.citations: Writing Next (explicit strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Clarity & Style (Plain Language)

Clarity comes from concrete subjects, active verbs, and concise phrasing. Plain language improves comprehension for expert and novice readers alike.

text:
Learning objectives for Clarity & Style (Plain Language):
Revise for strong subjects and verbs; prefer plain words.
Eliminate unnecessary nominalizations and clutter.

metadata.title: Clarity & Style (Plain Language)
metadata.retrieval_queries: plain language academic writing evidence | revising for clarity active verbs
metadata.citations: Writing Next (explicit strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Clarity & Style (Plain Language):
Revise for strong subjects and verbs; prefer plain words.
Eliminate unnecessary nominalizations and clutter.

text:
Misconception 1: Complex words equal smarter writing.
Refutation: Clarity shows mastery.
Explanation: Use precise, familiar words where possible.

metadata.title: Clarity & Style (Plain Language)
metadata.retrieval_queries: plain language academic writing evidence | revising for clarity active verbs
metadata.citations: Writing Next (explicit strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Complex words equal smarter writing.
Refutation: Clarity shows mastery.
Explanation: Use precise, familiar words where possible.

text:
Question 1: Which is clearer: ‘utilize’ or ‘use’?
Answer: use
Rationale: Short, familiar words aid processing.

Question 2: What should carry the sentence’s weight?
Answer: The verb
Rationale: Verbs move meaning; nominalizations often obscure it.

metadata.title: Clarity & Style (Plain Language)
metadata.retrieval_queries: plain language academic writing evidence | revising for clarity active verbs
metadata.citations: Writing Next (explicit strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which is clearer: ‘utilize’ or ‘use’?
Answer: use
Rationale: Short, familiar words aid processing.

Question 2: What should carry the sentence’s weight?
Answer: The verb
Rationale: Verbs move meaning; nominalizations often obscure it.

text:
Worked Example for Clarity & Style (Plain Language):
Step: Identify subjects; make them the agents of action. - Why: Aligns structure with meaning.
Step: Turn nominalizations into verbs where appropriate. - Why: Reduces clutter.
Step: Cut redundancies and hedge words that add no meaning. - Why: Tightens prose.
Step: Read aloud to test flow. - Why: Checks rhythm and clarity.

metadata.title: Clarity & Style (Plain Language)
metadata.retrieval_queries: plain language academic writing evidence | revising for clarity active verbs
metadata.citations: Writing Next (explicit strategy instruction) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Clarity & Style (Plain Language):
Step: Identify subjects; make them the agents of action. - Why: Aligns structure with meaning.
Step: Turn nominalizations into verbs where appropriate. - Why: Reduces clutter.
Step: Cut redundancies and hedge words that add no meaning. - Why: Tightens prose.
Step: Read aloud to test flow. - Why: Checks rhythm and clarity.

text:
Revision Strategies (HO → LO)

Revise meaning and structure before grammar. Use tools like reverse outlines, checklists, and peer feedback to target big wins first.

metadata.title: Revision Strategies (HO → LO)
metadata.retrieval_queries: revision higher order concerns checklist | reverse outline technique
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Revision Strategies (HO → LO)

Revise meaning and structure before grammar. Use tools like reverse outlines, checklists, and peer feedback to target big wins first.

text:
Learning objectives for Revision Strategies (HO → LO):
Sequence revisions from higher‑order to lower‑order concerns.
Use checklists and reverse outlines to focus effort.

metadata.title: Revision Strategies (HO → LO)
metadata.retrieval_queries: revision higher order concerns checklist | reverse outline technique
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Revision Strategies (HO → LO):
Sequence revisions from higher‑order to lower‑order concerns.
Use checklists and reverse outlines to focus effort.

text:
Misconception 1: Proofreading first saves time.
Refutation: It may be wasted when structure changes.
Explanation: Fix large issues before polishing.

metadata.title: Revision Strategies (HO → LO)
metadata.retrieval_queries: revision higher order concerns checklist | reverse outline technique
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Proofreading first saves time.
Refutation: It may be wasted when structure changes.
Explanation: Fix large issues before polishing.

text:
Question 1: Which should you address first: paragraph order or comma splices?
Answer: Paragraph order
Rationale: Big structural changes come first.

Question 2: What tool reveals structure–thesis alignment?
Answer: Reverse outline
Rationale: It shows each paragraph’s job.

metadata.title: Revision Strategies (HO → LO)
metadata.retrieval_queries: revision higher order concerns checklist | reverse outline technique
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which should you address first: paragraph order or comma splices?
Answer: Paragraph order
Rationale: Big structural changes come first.

Question 2: What tool reveals structure–thesis alignment?
Answer: Reverse outline
Rationale: It shows each paragraph’s job.

text:
Worked Example for Revision Strategies (HO → LO):
Step: Pass 1: thesis, structure, evidence integration. - Why: Higher‑order changes.
Step: Pass 2: clarity, concision, style and surface edits. - Why: Lower‑order refinement.
Step: Use a checklist to track fixes. - Why: Increases focus.
Step: Write a reflection on what changed and why. - Why: Reinforces learning.

metadata.title: Revision Strategies (HO → LO)
metadata.retrieval_queries: revision higher order concerns checklist | reverse outline technique
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Worked Example for Revision Strategies (HO → LO):
Step: Pass 1: thesis, structure, evidence integration. - Why: Higher‑order changes.
Step: Pass 2: clarity, concision, style and surface edits. - Why: Lower‑order refinement.
Step: Use a checklist to track fixes. - Why: Increases focus.
Step: Write a reflection on what changed and why. - Why: Reinforces learning.

text:
Using Feedback Productively

Feedback is most effective when it answers: Where am I going? How am I going? What next? Translate comments into concrete actions.

metadata.title: Using Feedback Productively
metadata.retrieval_queries: Hattie Timperley three questions feedback | actionable feedback writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Using Feedback Productively

Feedback is most effective when it answers: Where am I going? How am I going? What next? Translate comments into concrete actions.

text:
Learning objectives for Using Feedback Productively:
Interpret feedback by category (content, structure, evidence, style).
Draft an actionable revision plan from comments.

metadata.title: Using Feedback Productively
metadata.retrieval_queries: Hattie Timperley three questions feedback | actionable feedback writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Using Feedback Productively:
Interpret feedback by category (content, structure, evidence, style).
Draft an actionable revision plan from comments.

text:
Misconception 1: All feedback is equal.
Refutation: Prioritize by assignment goals.
Explanation: Address the highest‑impact issues first.

metadata.title: Using Feedback Productively
metadata.retrieval_queries: Hattie Timperley three questions feedback | actionable feedback writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: All feedback is equal.
Refutation: Prioritize by assignment goals.
Explanation: Address the highest‑impact issues first.

text:
Question 1: Which question is NOT central to good feedback per Hattie & Timperley? ‘Where am I going?’, ‘How am I going?’, or ‘Who am I?’
Answer: ‘Who am I?’
Rationale: Effective feedback targets task/process/self‑regulation, not self‑identity.

Question 2: Should you reply or act?
Answer: Act (with brief clarifying questions if needed)
Rationale: Actionable steps matter most.

metadata.title: Using Feedback Productively
metadata.retrieval_queries: Hattie Timperley three questions feedback | actionable feedback writing
metadata.citations: The Power of Feedback - Review of Educational Research (Hattie & Timperley, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which question is NOT central to good feedback per Hattie & Timperley? ‘Where am I going?’, ‘How am I going?’, or ‘Who am I?’
Answer: ‘Who am I?’
Rationale: Effective feedback targets task/process/self‑regulation, not self‑identity.

Question 2: Should you reply or act?
Answer: Act (with brief clarifying questions if needed)
Rationale: Actionable steps matter most.

text:
Worked Example for Using Feedback Productively:
Step: Categorize each comment (task/process/self‑regulation). - Why: Clarifies type.
Step: Write an action for each (e.g., add evidence in §2). - Why: Operationalizes change.
Step: Sequence actions (HO → LO). - Why: Maximizes impact.
Step: Reflect on what you’ll do differently next time. - Why: Builds metacognition.

text:
Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports

Lab reports use IMRaD structure to communicate what was done and found. Clarity and alignment between methods, results, and claims are crucial.

metadata.title: Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD sections purpose lab report | writing results and discussion best practices
metadata.citations: Writing Next (planning and summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports

Lab reports use IMRaD structure to communicate what was done and found. Clarity and alignment between methods, results, and claims are crucial.

text:
Learning objectives for Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports:
Apply IMRaD conventions to plan and draft a lab report.
Align claims with evidence and methods.

metadata.title: Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD sections purpose lab report | writing results and discussion best practices
metadata.citations: Writing Next (planning and summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports:
Apply IMRaD conventions to plan and draft a lab report.
Align claims with evidence and methods.

text:
Misconception 1: Discussion repeats results.
Refutation: It interprets findings and limits.
Explanation: Explain why results matter and what they don’t show.

metadata.title: Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD sections purpose lab report | writing results and discussion best practices
metadata.citations: Writing Next (planning and summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Discussion repeats results.
Refutation: It interprets findings and limits.
Explanation: Explain why results matter and what they don’t show.

text:
Question 1: Where should you present raw data?
Answer: Results (with clear visuals)
Rationale: Methods describes procedures, not outcomes.

Question 2: What belongs in Discussion?
Answer: Interpretation, limits, and future work
Rationale: It explains implications.

metadata.title: Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports
metadata.retrieval_queries: IMRaD sections purpose lab report | writing results and discussion best practices
metadata.citations: Writing Next (planning and summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Where should you present raw data?
Answer: Results (with clear visuals)
Rationale: Methods describes procedures, not outcomes.

Question 2: What belongs in Discussion?
Answer: Interpretation, limits, and future work
Rationale: It explains implications.

text:
Worked Example for Discipline‑Specific Genres: Lab Reports:
Step: Define the research question and hypothesis. - Why: Guides methods.
Step: List materials and procedures briefly. - Why: Supports reproducibility.
Step: Plan data tables/figures and captions. - Why: Clarifies results.
Step: Draft key claims for Discussion with caveats. - Why: Ensures alignment.

text:
Academic Integrity & Paraphrase

Integrity requires honest attribution and faithful representation of others’ ideas. Paraphrase by re‑expressing meaning; avoid near‑copying with synonym swaps.

metadata.title: Academic Integrity & Paraphrase
metadata.retrieval_queries: patchwriting vs paraphrase academic integrity | when to quote vs paraphrase
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction & summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Academic Integrity & Paraphrase

Integrity requires honest attribution and faithful representation of others’ ideas. Paraphrase by re‑expressing meaning; avoid near‑copying with synonym swaps.

text:
Learning objectives for Academic Integrity & Paraphrase:
Distinguish proper paraphrase from patchwriting.
Track sources, citations, and common knowledge carefully.

metadata.title: Academic Integrity & Paraphrase
metadata.retrieval_queries: patchwriting vs paraphrase academic integrity | when to quote vs paraphrase
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction & summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Academic Integrity & Paraphrase:
Distinguish proper paraphrase from patchwriting.
Track sources, citations, and common knowledge carefully.

text:
Misconception 1: Changing a few words is enough.
Refutation: It’s still patchwriting.
Explanation: Summarize and reframe ideas in your own structure, with citation.

metadata.title: Academic Integrity & Paraphrase
metadata.retrieval_queries: patchwriting vs paraphrase academic integrity | when to quote vs paraphrase
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction & summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Changing a few words is enough.
Refutation: It’s still patchwriting.
Explanation: Summarize and reframe ideas in your own structure, with citation.

text:
Question 1: Is this acceptable paraphrase: change 3 words and keep structure?
Answer: No
Rationale: That’s patchwriting; reframe and cite.

Question 2: What counts as common knowledge?
Answer: Widely known facts within a field
Rationale: When uncertain, cite or ask.

metadata.title: Academic Integrity & Paraphrase
metadata.retrieval_queries: patchwriting vs paraphrase academic integrity | when to quote vs paraphrase
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction & summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Is this acceptable paraphrase: change 3 words and keep structure?
Answer: No
Rationale: That’s patchwriting; reframe and cite.

Question 2: What counts as common knowledge?
Answer: Widely known facts within a field
Rationale: When uncertain, cite or ask.

text:
Worked Example for Academic Integrity & Paraphrase:
Step: Read, close the source, and write the idea in your own structure. - Why: Prevents patchwriting.
Step: Compare with original and adjust for meaning accuracy. - Why: Ensures fidelity.
Step: Cite the source in the required style. - Why: Gives credit.
Step: Add a note about how you’ll use it in your argument. - Why: Integrates purpose.

metadata.title: Academic Integrity & Paraphrase
metadata.retrieval_queries: patchwriting vs paraphrase academic integrity | when to quote vs paraphrase
metadata.citations: Writing Next (strategy instruction & summarization) - Carnegie Report (Graham & Perin, 2007)

Worked Example for Academic Integrity & Paraphrase:
Step: Read, close the source, and write the idea in your own structure. - Why: Prevents patchwriting.
Step: Compare with original and adjust for meaning accuracy. - Why: Ensures fidelity.
Step: Cite the source in the required style. - Why: Gives credit.
Step: Add a note about how you’ll use it in your argument. - Why: Integrates purpose.

text:
Presentations: Slides & Speaking

Good presentations apply multimedia principles: coherence, signaling, and minimal redundancy. Slides support your talk; they do not duplicate it.

metadata.title: Presentations: Slides & Speaking
metadata.retrieval_queries: coherence signaling redundancy principle presentation | slide design multimedia learning
metadata.citations: Multimedia Learning (2nd ed.) - Cambridge University Press (Mayer, 2009)
metadata.text:
Presentations: Slides & Speaking

Good presentations apply multimedia principles: coherence, signaling, and minimal redundancy. Slides support your talk; they do not duplicate it.

text:
Learning objectives for Presentations: Slides & Speaking:
Design clear slides using multimedia principles.
Deliver talks with structure and effective visuals.

metadata.title: Presentations: Slides & Speaking
metadata.retrieval_queries: coherence signaling redundancy principle presentation | slide design multimedia learning
metadata.citations: Multimedia Learning (2nd ed.) - Cambridge University Press (Mayer, 2009)
metadata.text:
Learning objectives for Presentations: Slides & Speaking:
Design clear slides using multimedia principles.
Deliver talks with structure and effective visuals.

text:
Misconception 1: Slides should include everything you will say.
Refutation: Slides should be minimalist.
Explanation: Use visuals and cues; keep text brief.

metadata.title: Presentations: Slides & Speaking
metadata.retrieval_queries: coherence signaling redundancy principle presentation | slide design multimedia learning
metadata.citations: Multimedia Learning (2nd ed.) - Cambridge University Press (Mayer, 2009)
metadata.text:
Misconception 1: Slides should include everything you will say.
Refutation: Slides should be minimalist.
Explanation: Use visuals and cues; keep text brief.

text:
Question 1: Which pairing is better: dense text + reading it aloud, or visuals + spoken explanation?
Answer: Visuals + spoken explanation
Rationale: Avoid redundancy; support dual channels effectively.

Question 2: Should you memorize every word?
Answer: No
Rationale: Learn the structure and key transitions instead.

metadata.title: Presentations: Slides & Speaking
metadata.retrieval_queries: coherence signaling redundancy principle presentation | slide design multimedia learning
metadata.citations: Multimedia Learning (2nd ed.) - Cambridge University Press (Mayer, 2009)
metadata.text:
Question 1: Which pairing is better: dense text + reading it aloud, or visuals + spoken explanation?
Answer: Visuals + spoken explanation
Rationale: Avoid redundancy; support dual channels effectively.

Question 2: Should you memorize every word?
Answer: No
Rationale: Learn the structure and key transitions instead.

text:
Worked Example for Presentations: Slides & Speaking:
Step: Strip decorative elements and reduce text. - Why: Coherence principle.
Step: Add cues (arrows/color) to highlight key parts. - Why: Signaling principle.
Step: Use large, readable visuals; keep text to phrases. - Why: Cognitive load management.
Step: Practice a 1‑minute explanation per slide. - Why: Aligns speech with visuals.
